segments.text: It was on the ninth of November, the eve of his own thirty‐eighth birthday, as he often remembered afterwards. Dorian Gray was walking home about eleven o’clock from Lord Henry’s, having dined in the warm atmosphere of a gentleman’s club. Wrapped in heavy furs against the cold, foggy night, he ambled along the corner of Grosvenor Square and South Audley Street. Through the mist he noticed a man, hurrying past with the collar of his grey ulster turned up and a bag in his hand—a man Dorian recognized as Basil Hallward. A strange, inexplicable fear seized him, and without a sign of recognition he quickened his pace toward his house.

voice_traits.pacing: moderate, with deliberate pauses on key details

segments.text: Dorian! What an extraordinary piece of luck! I have been waiting for you in your library ever since nine o’clock. Finally I took pity on your tired servant and told him to go to bed as he let me out. I am off to Paris by the midnight train, and I particularly wanted to see you before I left. I thought it was you—or rather, your fur coat—as you passed me. But I wasn’t quite sure. Didn’t you recognize me?

voice_traits.pauses: brief pauses after exclamations

segments.text: In this fog, my dear Basil? Why, I can’t even recognize Grosvenor Square. I believe my house must be somewhere about here, but I don’t feel at all certain. I am sorry you are going away, as I haven’t seen you for ages. But I suppose you will be back soon?
segments.emotion: lightly bemused, with a hint of regret

voice_traits.pauses: slight pauses at commas

segments.text: No: I am going to be out of England for six months. I intend to take a studio in Paris and shut myself up until I have finished the great picture I have in my head. However, it wasn’t about myself I wanted to talk about. Here we are at your door—let me come in for a moment. I have something to say to you.
segments.emotion: earnest, with a tinge of melancholy determination

voice_traits.pauses: a brief pause after declaring his travel plans

segments.text: I shall be charmed. But won’t you miss your train?

voice_traits.pauses: a slight pause before the question

segments.text: Dorian unlocked his door with his latch-key and stepped inside. Outside, the lamplight fought its way through the fog. Basil glanced at his watch—nonchalantly noting, 'I have heaps of time; the train doesn’t go till twelve-fifteen, and it is only just eleven.' The air was cool, and as they proceeded together, the scene shifted to the warm and inviting interior of Dorian’s library, where a bright wood fire blazed in the large open hearth, lamps lit the room, and an open Dutch silver spirit-case caught the light on a small marqueterie table.

voice_traits.emotion: calm with an undercurrent of tension
voice_traits.pauses: longer pauses on scene changes

segments.text: What a way for a fashionable painter to travel! A Gladstone bag and an ulster! Come in, or the fog will get into the house. And mind you, don’t talk about anything serious. Nothing is serious nowadays. At least nothing should be.

voice_traits.pronunciation: clear with slight emphasis on key adjectives
voice_traits.pauses: minor pauses for effect after each remark

segments.text: You see, your servant made me feel quite at home, Dorian. He provided everything I desired—even your best gold-tipped cigarettes. I must say, I prefer him by far to the Frenchman you once employed. By the by, what has become of that Frenchman?

voice_traits.pacing: steady with a slight inquisitive lilt
voice_traits.pauses: short pauses after each observation

segments.text: I believe he married Lady Radley’s maid and has established her in Paris as an English dressmaker. Anglomanie is all the rage over there now—how odd for the French, isn’t it? Though he wasn’t a bad servant in his own way, I had little to complain about. Devoted and regretful upon his departure, in his own peculiar manner. Will you have another brandy-and-soda? Or perhaps hock-and-seltzer? I always take hock-and-seltzer myself. I’m sure there’s some in the next room.
segments.emotion: detached, conversational with an undercurrent of irony

voice_traits.pauses: regular pauses between humorous asides

segments.text: Now, my dear fellow, I want to speak to you seriously. Don’t frown like that—you only make it harder for me.

voice_traits.pauses: a brief pause after the address

segments.text: What is it all about? I hope it isn’t about myself—I’m tired of myself tonight. I should like to be somebody else.

voice_traits.accent: refined with a hint of world-weariness
voice_traits.pronunciation: clipped with a touch of sarcasm
voice_traits.pauses: short, staccato bursts

segments.text: It is about yourself, Dorian, and I must tell you so. I shall only keep you for half an hour.

voice_traits.pauses: a slight pause before the time remark

segments.text: Half an hour!

voice_traits.pauses: none

segments.text: It is not much to ask, Dorian, and it is entirely for your own sake that I insist on speaking. I think it only right that you know the dreadful things being said about you in London.

voice_traits.pronunciation: clear, deliberate, with weighted emphasis on 'dreadful'
voice_traits.pauses: a measured pause after the opening clause

segments.text: I don’t wish to know anything about them. I love scandals about other people, but scandals about myself lose their novelty. My reputation—my private life and the gossip of London—it matters little to me.

voice_traits.pronunciation: crisp with a sneer apparent in his delivery
voice_traits.pauses: short, biting pauses

segments.text: Yet every gentleman is concerned about his good name, Dorian. You mustn’t let them speak of you as vile and degraded. Your position and wealth taste sweet, but they are not everything. Sin leaves its mark—on the lines of one’s face, in the droop of the eyelids, even in the moulding of his hands. I once turned away a man—someone whose very gesture repelled me—for an extravagant price. I was right to shun him; his life is a horror. And yet, you, with your pure, bright, innocent face and seemingly untroubled youth... I scarcely see you anymore, and when you are abroad in your studio, dreadful murmurs follow your every step. Why is it that a man like the Duke of Berwick exits a club as soon as you enter? Why do so many respectable London gentlemen shun your company or refuse your invitation?

voice_traits.pacing: slow, with deliberate enunciation of key points
voice_traits.pronunciation: each word carefully enunciated with gravity
voice_traits.pauses: extended pauses after rhetorical questions

segments.text: Stop, Basil. You speak of matters you scarcely understand. Is it because I know every sordid detail of another’s life that you decry my presence? I have not taught anyone to sin. If the Duke of Berwick’s blood is stained, that is his fate alone. And if Henry Ashton, young Perth, or even Lord Kent’s foolish son find themselves mired in scandal, why should I be blamed for their weakness? In England, everyone seems eager to wag their tongues—those same middle-class chattering them into believing that propriety is measured solely by association. We live in the native land of hypocrisy, my friend.

voice_traits.pacing: rapid and clipped, as though trying to outrun the criticism
voice_traits.pronunciation: precise, with underlined sharpness on key insults
voice_traits.pauses: brief, pointed pauses between accusations

segments.text: Dorian, that is not the point. England is corrupt, and its society is awry. That is why I wish for you to be better—to be fine. Your influence over your friends has led them into debauchery. Your reputation casts a shadow that corrupts those near you. It is said that your very presence drags down the character of even the most upright gentleman. I recall Lord Gloucester, one of my dearest friends from Oxford, who once showed me a dying letter implicating you in the most terrible confession. I told him it was preposterous; I know you, and you could never do such a thing. And yet… I wonder, Dorian, do I truly know you? Before I can answer, I must see your soul.

voice_traits.pacing: slow and measured, allowing each lament to sink in
voice_traits.pauses: long, reflective pauses especially before the final demand

segments.text: To see my soul!

voice_traits.emotion: terror mixed with a mocking disbelief
voice_traits.pauses: a heavy pause following the exclamation
voice_traits.speech_patterns: short, almost whispery betrayal of vulnerability

segments.text: Yes, to see your soul. But only God can do that.

voice_traits.pronunciation: clear with a weight of finality
voice_traits.pauses: a measured pause before the final clause

segments.text: You shall see it yourself tonight! Look at it—your very handiwork. Why not expose it to the world? If they believe, they may even like me more for it. I know the times better than you do, though you prate endlessly. Enough of the chatter about corruption. Now, face it squarely!

voice_traits.emotion: arrogant defiance mixed with dark glee
voice_traits.pauses: sharp breaks between statements to heighten tension

segments.text: This is blasphemy, Dorian! You must not speak such horrible things—they mean nothing!

voice_traits.pauses: a significant pause after the exclamation

segments.text: You think so? (laughs bitterly) I’ve seen the age for what it is. Now, come upstairs, Basil. I keep a diary of my life from day to day—a record that never leaves the room in which it is written. I will show it to you if you follow me.
segments.emotion: cold, challenging with a hint of mockery

voice_traits.emotion: defiant detachment mixed with dark amusement
voice_traits.pauses: a measured pause between the challenge and the invitation

segments.text: I shall come with you, Dorian, if you wish it. I see I have missed my train, but that matters not. Tomorrow will suffice. However, do not expect me to read anything tonight; all I want is a plain answer to your question.

voice_traits.tone: softly admonishing with an undercurrent of sadness
voice_traits.emotion: tired resignation mixed with honest worry
voice_traits.pauses: slight pauses to indicate weariness

segments.text: That answer shall be given upstairs. I could not possibly speak of these things here.

voice_traits.pauses: a brief pause after 'upstairs'
